problem: Prove that there are infinitely many primes with last digit 7.
solutions:
Assume for contradiction that there are only finitely many primes with last digit 7, and let them be \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\). Consider the number \(N = 10\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_i + 7\). Clearly, \(N\) ends in 7 and is greater than each \(p_i\).

Since \(N\) is not divisible by any prime ending in 7 (by construction), if \(N\) is prime, we have found a prime ending in 7 not in our list, a contradiction. If \(N\) is not prime, it must have a prime factor not in our list, since otherwise, \(N\) would be divisible by 10, which it is not (its last digit is 7). Any prime factor of \(N\) not among \(p_1, \ldots, p_n\) that divides \(N\) cannot end in 1, 3, or 9, for such a factor would make \(N\) end in a digit other than 7, given the form of \(N\). Thus, this prime factor must end in 7, providing the contradiction. 

Hence, there must be infinitely many primes with last digit 7.

Consider the numbers of the form \(10k + 7\) where \(k\) is a natural number. Clearly, some of these numbers must be prime, or else they would all have prime factors other than themselves, implying that all primes divide some number of the form \(10m\), which is not possible since there are primes that do not divide 10 directly.

Assume for contradiction that there are only finitely many primes of the form \(10k + 7\), say \(p_1, p_2, ..., p_n\). Consider the number \(N = 10(p_1p_2...p_n) - 3\). Note that \(N\) ends in a 7 because \(10 \times \text{anything} - 3\) will always end in 7. 

For each \(p_i\) in our finite list, \(N\) is obviously not divisible by \(p_i\) since \(N + 3 = 10(p_1p_2...p_n)\) is divisible by \(p_i\), but \(N\) would leave a remainder of 3 upon division by \(p_i\), not 0. Hence, \(N\) has a prime factor that is not in our list, which contradicts our assumption that we have listed all primes of the form \(10k + 7\).

Therefore, there must be infinitely many primes with the last digit 7.

Suppose there are only finitely many primes with last digit 7, say \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\). Consider the number \(N = 10\cdot(p_1p_2 \cdots p_n) - 3\). Clearly, \(N\) ends in 7. Also, \(N\) is not divisible by any of \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\), for if it were, \(10\cdot(p_1p_2 \cdots p_n)\) would leave a remainder of 3 upon division by any of these primes, which is impossible. Hence, either \(N\) itself is a prime number ending in 7, which is not in the list \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\), or it has a prime divisor that ends in 7 and is not among \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\). In either case, we have a contradiction. Therefore, there must be infinitely many primes with last digit 7.
theories:
## Theorem
There are infinitely many primes with last digit 7.

### Proof
Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that the set of all primes with last digit 7 is finite. Let this set be denoted by \(S = \{p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\}\), where \(n\) is a positive integer. Consider the number \(N = 10\prod_{i=1}^{n}p_i + 7\). By construction, \(N\) ends in 7 and is strictly greater than any \(p_i\) in \(S\).

First, note that \(N\) is not divisible by any prime in \(S\) since if a prime \(p_i\) in \(S\) divided \(N\), then \(N\) would be congruent to 7 modulo \(p_i\), which contradicts the construction of \(N\).

If \(N\) itself is prime, then it is a prime with last digit 7 not included in our original set \(S\), contradicting our assumption that \(S\) contains all such primes.

If \(N\) is composite, it must have a prime factor not in \(S\). This prime factor cannot end in 1, 3, or 9 without forcing \(N\) to end in a digit other than 7, due to the multiplicative properties of the decimal system. Therefore, any new prime factor of \(N\) must end in 7, providing a contradiction to our original assumption that all primes ending in 7 are contained in \(S\).

Thus, under both possible conditions for \(N\), we arrive at a contradiction, implying our original assumption that there are only finitely many primes with last digit 7 is false. Therefore, there must be infinitely many primes with last digit 7.

## Theorem
There are infinitely many primes with the last digit 7.

### Proof
Consider the arithmetic progression defined by \(10k + 7\) for \(k \in \mathbb{N}\). We aim to show that this progression contains infinitely many primes. 

**Step 1**: Observe that if there were only finitely many such primes, say \(p_1, p_2, ..., p_n\), we can construct a particular number that leads to a contradiction.

**Step 2**: Construct the number \(N = 10(p_1p_2...p_n) - 3\). By construction, \(N\) ends in 7, fitting the form of numbers we are considering.

**Step 3**: We show that \(N\) cannot be divisible by any of the primes \(p_1, p_2, ..., p_n\). For any \(p_i\), \(N + 3 = 10(p_1p_2...p_n)\) is divisible by \(p_i\), but \(N\) leaves a remainder of 3 when divided by \(p_i\), not zero.

**Step 4**: Since \(N\) is not divisible by any \(p_i\), and since it is greater than 1 and ends in 7, it must have a prime factor that is not in our initial list and similarly ends in 7. This contradicts our assumption of having listed all such primes.

**Conclusion**: By contradiction, there must be infinitely many primes that end in the digit 7.

**Theorem:** There are infinitely many primes with the last digit 7.

**Proof:** Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that there exists a finite number of primes whose last digit is 7, denoted as \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\). Construct the number \(N = 10\cdot(p_1p_2 \cdots p_n) - 3\). It is evident that \(N\) ends in 7. Moreover, \(N\) cannot be divisible by any of the primes \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\). To see this, note that if \(N\) were divisible by any \(p_i\) (for some \(i\) between 1 and \(n\)), then \(10\cdot(p_1p_2 \cdots p_n)\) would yield a remainder of 3 upon division by \(p_i\), which is a contradiction since \(p_i\) divides \(10\cdot(p_1p_2 \cdots p_n)\) perfectly. Therefore, \(N\) is either prime itself, contradicting the assumption that all primes ending in 7 are among \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\), or it has a prime divisor not in the list \(p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n\) that necessarily ends in 7, contradicting the assumption of finiteness. Thus, our initial assumption must be false, implying the infinitude of primes with the last digit 7.
